title-group.article-title: Internal wave transport, nonlinear manifestation, and mixing in a stratified shear layer - technical briefs

article-meta.aff: 1Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, Pingtung, Taiwan
2Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center (GEODAC), National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan
3Department of Information Management, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Yuan Chen, Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, No. 4–18, Ming Shen Rd., Pingtung 90003, Taiwan Email: cyc@mail.npue.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Internal solitary waves (ISWs) have been detected at the interface of a stratified water column in the laboratory. This paper reports upon the propagation of an ISW in various pycnoclines. The thickness of the pycnocline was estimated from the resulting density profile in the vertical direction. Based on the results obtained, the dimensionless thickness (= B/H, where B is pycnocline; H the total depth of 50 cm) of the first test was 0-0.1 in ISW. Experimental results show that, as the thickness of the pycnoline increases, the values of all the physical parameters (e.g., wave amplitude, phase speed, and wave energy) decreases. The findings of this study should be beneficial to oceanography and advanced research regarding ISW propagation and the evolution of both laboratory experiments and in-situ measurements.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The temperature of a water column in the ocean varies continuously. The simplest density structure with which it can be approximated is a stratified two-layer system. The layer of enhanced vertical stratification below the surface, at the interface between any two layers of different densities is called the pycnocline. In all field experiments internal waves have been found at the depth of this changing density profile. In fact the properties of this pycnocline seem to influence the form and location of the observed internal gravity waves (IGWs). The thickness of a pycnocline is finite which differs from the theoretical assumption of being an ultra-thin layer. Of course, observations through the water column (at several depths) are required to know all the characteristics of an internal wave train, however studies related to this theme have been rather rare.

sec.title: 2. Literature reviews
sec.p: Currently, a number of reports on the observations of IGWs can be found in relevant works regarding the ocean, lakes, fjords and even the atmosphere (Farmer and Freeland, 1983; Hibiya, 1988; Stacey et al., 1995; Dunkerton, 1997; Saucier and Chasse, 2000; Valle-Levinson, 2001; Cummins et al., 2003). Although exploring the properties of the ocean is not always an easy task, there have been observations of oceanic internal solitary waves (ISWs) since the beginning of the 20th century. Some in-situ internal waves are large enough in amplitude (100 m or more) to affect oil drilling operations (Bole et al., 1994; Martin et al., 1998), nutrient pumping (Cacchione et al., 2002; Noble and Xu, 2003), and acoustic signal obstruction (Katz, 1967; Lynch et al., 1996; Rubenstein, 1999).

In the South China Sea (SCS) interfacial solitary waves (ISWs) or internal waves (IWs) may be generated by the interaction between tidal currents or surface gravity waves and the submerged topography in the region, such as the two high ridges across the Luzon Strait between Taiwan and the Philippines. While propagating across the northern SCS, an ISW may undergo numerous transformations, such as wave breaking, an internal hydraulic jump, vertical vortex formation on the frontal slope of a submerged obstacle, wave refraction and diffraction as it shoals in the vicinity of a large island, and eventually waveform inversion on a shallow shelf. A large ISW can not only affect oil drilling operations (Bole et al., 1994), but also produce turbulent mixing (Moum et al., 2003). This could cause nutrient pumping and induce fish to forage (Corredor, 2008). In the SCS, for example, ISWs with an amplitude of up to 170 m, as well as a velocity difference between the upper and bottom layer exceeding 3.4 ms-1 (Warn-Varnas et al., 2010) have been observed. Moreover, pilot whales have been found to follow ISWs in the SCS (Moore and Lien, 2007). Wang et al. (2007) also observed the ecological processes induced by ISWs propagating beyond Dongsha Atoll, an isolated ring reef in the northwestern SCS. Available reports indicate that two of the most important characteristics of ISW propagation over submarine topography are the generation of vortices with strong turbulent mixing in the water column and the waveform inversion on a slope or continental shelf.

Despite the widely accepted belief among oceanographers that the inversion may commence at the turning point, the understanding of the process of waveform evolution during depression ISW shoaling still remains rather limited. Ideally, waveform inversion is expected to commence at the turning point where the upper layer (h1) and the lower layer (h2) are equal in depth. An ISW in the depression stage would become unsettled once it enters shallow water where h1 > h2; it will eventually be transformed into an elevation IW with a favourable depth ratio (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Theoretical representation showing the shoaling of internal waves in the depression phase after passing a turning point and waveform inversion on a continental shelf.

sec.title: 3. Experimental set-up
sec.p:
Recently, a variety of computer techniques have been successfully developed and applied to nonlinear problems, such as robot manipulation, engineering applications and construction management (Almutairi and Zribi, 2009; Amini and Vahdani, 2009; Chen, 2006, 2009a,b, 2010a,b,c, 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i, 2012a,b,c; Chen and Chen, 2010; Chen and Huang, 2011; Chen and Saif, 2010; Chen et al., 2005a,b; 2006a,b,c; 2007a,b,c,d,e,f; 2008a,b,c,d,e; 2009a,b,c,d,e,f; 2010a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h; 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h; 2012a,b,c,d; Cheng et al., 2011; Chiang et al., 2010; Chiang and Wang, 2011; Chiou et al., 2011; Chu et al., 2011; Guclu and Metin, 2009; Hsiao et al., 2005a,b,c,d,e; Hsieh et al., 2006; Hsu et al., 2011; Jayaswal et al., 2011; Kuo and Chen, 2011, 2012a,b; Kuo et al., 2011; Lee and Chen, 2012; Lee et al., 2010a,b; 2011a,b,c; Li et al., 2010; Lin and Chao, 2009; Lin and Chen, 2010, 2011, 2012; Lin et al., 2009a,b; 2010c; 2011a,b; 2012a,b; Liu et al., 2011a,b; 2012a,b; Marichal et al., 2011; Metin and Guclu, 2011; Omurlu et al., 2009; Shen et al., 2011; Shih et al., 2010a,b,c,d; 2011a,b,c,d; Solihin et al., 2010; 2011a,b,c; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011; Su et al., 2012; Tang et al., 2011; Tsai and Chen, 2011a,b; Tsai et al., 2008; Tseng and Chen, 2012; Tseng et al., 2012a,b,c; Tu et al., 2009; Tusset et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2008a,b; Yeh et al., 2008; 2012; Yu et al., 2011a,b; Zhao et al., 2009). These techniques are helpful to set up an experimental environment. For this study, experiments were conducted in a 12 m long wave flume with a rectangular cross-section (0.5 × 0.7 m; see Figure 2), in which a vertically removable sluice gate was mounted on the right-hand side (with an observer facing the flume) for generating internal waves. A density difference was produced in the two-layer fluid system in the laboratory by utilizing an upper layer of fresh water with density ρ1, to a depth H1, and a lower layer of briny water with density ρ2. The latter was premixed separately in a storage tank and then added slowly by gravity to a depth of H2 through several small openings along the bottom of the flume. A mini pump was used to remove a small quantity of fresh water from the main section of the flume to the small compartment behind the vertical gate. A corresponding mass of briny water then slowly moved to the other side of the gate through a narrow gap between the bottom of the gate and the flume bottom, thus maintaining a hydrostatic balance. This created the prescribed step difference ηo at the interface levels on either side of the gate. The initial internal wave was generated by raising the movable gate using a pneumatic device controlled by a switch allowing the fresh water to overturn the briny water, causing a leading solitary wave to propagate across the flume. The primary internal wave developed into a leading solitary wave propagating ahead of a transient dispersive wave train. Once the thickness of the fresh water in the small compartment was greater than that in main section of the flume, clockwise overturning on the interface level grew while raising the gate, and vice versa. The evolution of a depression-type internal wave resulted due to clockwise interface overturning; on theother hand, elevation-type internal waves could be generated by counterclockwise interface overturning. Figure 2.
Schematic representation of the laboratory set-up for internal wave propagation in a stratification layer fluid system.

A total of six ultrasonic probes were connected to an amplifier unit and an A/D converter, and the digital signals of the internal wave fluctuations were processed using the Multi Node Data Acquisition System (MNDAS) software. In each test run, observations were carried out on the generation of an internal wave in the flume by raising the movable gate. It was seen that the waves propagated over a constant depth and ran-up onto the slope. In order to minimize the attenuation of pycnocline diffusion, test runs were first carried out with waves of smaller amplitude to minimize mixing at the interface, followed by progressively larger amplitudes. In this manner, the initinal interface was able to support five to six tests before the flue had to be drained and refilled.
Hence, each experimental number covers some five to six runs using waves from small to large amplitudes to cover a wide range of wave energies.

No wave absorbing facilities were introduced at either end of the flume; thus incident waves were free to be reflected back to the test section between the slope and the gate. Once the newly generated wave reached a stable form a short distance from its source, an ISW appeared to propagate at a constant depth in the main section of the flume. The fluctuations of the interface (i.e., ISW) were recorded using ultrasonic probes placed at pre-arranged positions along the flume, as shown in Figure 2. Examples of the time series of the first five probes of an ISW propagating in the flume are given in Figure 3.The initial peak at probe P1 was approximately 80 mm high, but it was then reduced to about 70 mm, after propagating all the way down to probe P5. Upon encountering the sloping boundary, there was slight reduction in wave height and the base of the wave profile widened. The height of the reflected peak remained about 60 mm (after returning to probe P1). The material nature of a rigid slope and impermeable bottom plane allowed the internal wave to be reflected back and forth while propagating in the flume. Hence it can be concluded that the wave attenuation by energy damping might primarily originate from the effects of viscosity. From the onset of wave generation, the ISWs would dissipate almost completely within 10–15 min. The first dashed line on the far left in Figure 2 marks the route of a soliton from P1 to P5, which is eventually reflected back and forth in the flume. The gradient of the first and second slanted lines indicate wave speeds of about 122 mm/s for the incident wave and around 118 mm/s for the reflected wave during its first journey. According to the recorded wave profiles in Figure 2, time intervals between the peak of the first leading wave and the second one increased with time. The time interval is 8 s for P1, and approximately 18 s upon arriving at P5 near the toe of the slope. Figure 3.
Vertical distribution of the density profile.

sec.title: 4. Density profile
sec.p: At the beginning and the end of each test run, the vertical distribution of fluid density was measured by a density probe mounted in the middle section of the wave flume. The vertical distribution of the density profile (Figure 3) showed a near perfect two-layer system of fresh-brine water before the run and a diffused state after test runs. The depth ratio of the upper to bottom layer was H1/H2 = 15 cm/35cm with an upper density ρ1 = 999 g/cm3, bottom density ρ2 = 1020 g/cm3, and step difference η0 = 15 cm. These values indicate density variation in the vertical direction, and the abscissa indicates the ratio of density difference between the ambient and upper layer of fluid to that between the two layers before and after each run. The ordinate at z = 0 cm was the original interface (defined as positive upward). In all cases, the initial thickness of the pycnocline was within or much less than 1 cm and this thickness increased with the number of test runs. Diffusion of fluid at the interface due to disturbances and mixing was apparent after a test run.

sec.title: 5. Pycnocline
sec.p:
After generating ISWs 15 times (f) by raising the movable gate, we compared the difference between the depth ratio H1/H2 and step difference ηo, as demonstrated in Figure 4. The variables were arranged for four different depth ratios of H1/H2 = 10/40, 15/35, 35/15, and 40/10, and for a two step difference ηo = 10 cm and 15 cm. Therefore, a total of 120 runs were carried out with 15 test runs for 8 control conditions. Based on the evidence shown in Figure 4, it can be seen that large step differences resulted in incensement on the pycnocline. Furthermore, under a constant step difference and depth parameter |H2-H1|/H, the pycnocline is thicker for H1/H2 = 40/10 than H1/H2 = 10/40. It is evident that, for case of H1/H2 = 40/10, an elevation ISW propagating in the flume would cause more significant internal mixing than a depression ISW in the case of H1/H2 = 10/40. This condition is especially apparent in the cases with large depth parameters. The common stratification pattern in the ocean is for there to be an extremely thin upper layer and thick bottom layer. With this arrangement, the pycnocline seems to remain constant in spite of repeated wave propagation in the ocean. Obviously, as the number of times ISWs are generated in the flume increases, the pycnocline tends to remain apparently stable as a kappa curve. For instance, the pycnocline is quite close to 14 cm (B/H = 0.3, H = 50 cm) for H1/H2 = 15/35 and ηo = 15 cm when the x-axis increases. It is evident that the pycnocline reached a constant value (see point distribution in Figure 4) when the f value surpassed 10 regardless of the control condition. Figure 4.
Non-dimensional pycnocline (B/H) plotted against times (f) of internal solitary waves generated by raising the movable gate.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: A series of laboratory experiments were carried out in a wave flume 12 m long, 0.5 m wide, and 0.7 m high. The total water depth was 0.5 m. The fluid density and thickness are indicated by ρ1, H1, and ρ2, H2 for the upper and lower layers, respectively. We especially studied the effect of the thickness of the pycnocline on wave characteristics including amplitude, energy, and speed of an ISW. We illustrate and quantify the resultant properties of an ISW for different depth ratios. The results are also considered and the difference between an ISW of the elevation type and the depression type compared. The findings of this study should be of benefit to ocanography and advanced reseach in ISW propagation and evolution, both in laboratory experiments and in-situ measurements.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author is appreciative of the financial support of his funding bodies. The author is also most grateful for the kind assistance of Professor Ali Nayfeh, Editor of JVC, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which has led to the making of several corrections and have greatly aided him to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Science Council, Republic of China (grant numbers NSC 99-2628-E-153-001 and NSC 100-2628-E-153-001).
